Department of Physics Faculty of Science Khon Kaen University Khon Kaen 40002 Thailand The present work investigated the biolubricant production from palm oil-based methyl ester over calcium methoxide nanocatalyst. The hydrothermal method was employed in this work to prepare nano-calcium methoxide. The difference of hydrothermal synthesis time influenced on the catalytic characteristics and performances was studied. The catalytic activity showed a significant dependence on the catalyst's basic sites and particle size, achieving a palm oil methyl ester conversion of 78–89 % and a selectivity of 62–80 % for biolubricant production. The calcium methoxide with a hydrothermal synthesis time of 6 h exhibited superior catalytic activity to the other catalysts as a result of its small particle size and high basicity. Additionally, the calcium methoxide catalyst apparently showed good stability and reutilization, with palm oil methyl ester conversion of 85 % after use for 6 consecutive cycles. The physicochemical properties of the obtained biolubricant aligned closely the ISO VG 46 mineral oil, especially regarding viscosity and flash point. However, due to its high pour point, the obtained biolubricant may be most suitable for applications in tropical climates without winter conditions Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biolubricant Palm oil methyl ester Calcium methoxide Hydrothermal synthesis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Lubricants are generally used in industry and automotive to reduce friction, heat loss, and wear from moving contact surfaces, with consumption estimated at 30–40 million tons annually [1]. Approximately 85∼90 % of global lubricant is derived from petroleum-based that composes of paraffinic or naphthenic hydrocarbons containing 20–50 carbon atoms. Petroleum-derived lubricating oil is non-renewable and toxic to humans and environment. Without proper disposal, about 50 % of used lubricants will be released into the environment which includes soil, groundwater and air. As a result, finding alternatives to petroleum-based lubricants has attracted worldwide interest. In recent years, biolubricant derived from vegetable oil have been considered as potential replacements for petroleum-derived lubricating oil [2,3]. Trimethylolpropane triesters (TE) are a vegetable oil-based polyol esters that have been identified as a potential biodegradable lubricant owing to its excellent viscosity index (VI), lubricity, stability, low volatility and biodegradability [4]. Synthesis of TE can be achieved via transesterification and esterification reactions. The latter method was reportedly superior to former method to produce polyol ester owing to its inexpensive and high energy efficiency. The transesterification usually occurs with the use of a catalyst through three consecutive reactions as shown in Eqs. (1) – (3). (1) TMP + POME ↔ ME + CH3OH (2) TMP + ME ↔ DE + CH3OH (3) TMP + DE ↔ TE + CH3OH First, POME reacts with trimethylolpropane (TMP) to form monoester (ME) of TMP. Second, ME will react with another POME molecule to form diesters (DE). Finally, DE will follow the same process to produce triester (TE). At the end of the reaction, one ester molecule and three methanol molecules are generated [5]. Heterogeneous catalysts have been widely employed in transesterification reactions because of their easy separation from the product, reusability, and less corrosion [6]. Amongst heterogeneous catalysts, calcium oxide (CaO) has most frequently been applied and reveals an excellent catalytic performance for transesterification [7]. Nevertheless, the rate of catalytic reaction is relatively slow and requires extreme reaction conditions such as elevated temperatures and prolonged reaction times. Thus, the catalyst seems not to be adaptable for commercial applications. According to the literature, the catalytic activity of alkaline-earth metal oxide can be improved by converting it to metal alkoxide. Liu et al. [8] employed CaO, calcium hydroxide (Ca(OH)2) and calcium methoxide Ca(OCH3)2 as catalysts for biodiesel production from triglycerides and found that Ca(OCH3)2 catalyst exhibited stronger basicity and higher catalytic performance yielding biodiesel of 98 % within 2 h reaction time. The order of activity of the solid catalysts was Ca(OCH3)2 > CaO > Ca(OH)2, in agreement with the Lewis basic theory (Liu et al., 2008) [8]. In addition to the basicity, the catalyst activity can be improved by decreasing its particles. This can be achieved by preparing a catalyst in a nano-form. Recently, CaO and Ca(OCH3)2 nanocatalysts were successfully synthesized using hydrothermal method and the difference in hydrothermal conditions resulted in a range of morphologies such as cubic crystal, spherical, plate like and star-like structures [9,10]. Teo et al. [11] studied the impact of hydrothermal parameters on the catalytic properties and activities of Ca(OCH3)2 for biodiesel production and found that synthesis time played a key role in structural and physicochemical characteristics of catalyst which significantly affected on transesterification activity [11]. Therefore, to improve catalytic performance decreasing the crystal size of catalyst is one key step. The investigation of Ca(OCH3)2 as a catalyst for the biolubricant production has been reported in the literature and various parameters were investigated to increase the performance of the catalyst. However, few systematic studies on the effect of hydrothermal synthesis parameters on its physico-chemical property and catalytic activity have been reported. This research studied the influence of hydrothermal synthesis time on catalyst characteristics including surface area, pore size, particle size, basicity, and stability, while establishing direct correlations with transesterification efficiency for converting POME into biolubricant, an aspect that has not been reported previously. A comprehensive characterization was performed by TG/DTA, FTIR, FESEM, XRD, BET, CO2-TPD, XPS and TGA-MS to clarify the relationship between catalyst characteristics and performances. Additionally, catalyst deactivation mechanisms were assessed using ICP-AES to analyze Ca leaching over multiple reusability cycles. Statistical analysis, including correlation coefficients (R²) and regression modeling, was performed to quantify and validate the relationships between catalyst characteristics and TE yield. The findings contributed to optimizing Ca(OCH₃)₂ catalysts, improving their activity, stability, reusability, and efficiency. These findings provide a foundation for the development of more efficient and sustainable catalysts for biolubricant production. 2 Experiment 2.1 Materials Palm oil-based methyl ester (POME) was supported from BBGI Bio Diesel Company Limited (Thailand). The POME consisted of palmitic acid methyl ester of 44.28 %, oleic acid methyl ester of 39.86 %, linoleic acid methyl ester of 9.26 % and stearic acid methyl ester of 4.13 %, respectively. Trimethylolpropane, 2-ethyl-2-hydroxymethyl-1,3-propanediol (TMP) (assay >98 %) purum grade, calcium oxide (CaO) (analytical grade), methanol (GC grade) and hexane (GC grade) were supplied by Sigma-Aldrich 2.2 Catalyst preparation CaO catalyst: CaO (30 g) was calcined at 850 °C during a 3-hour period. Ca(OCH 3 ) 2 catalyst: 5 g of the calcined CaO was suspended into100 mL methanol followed by a continuous stirring at 65 °C under nitrogen flow. The reflux times were 2, 4, 6 and 8 h. After the corresponding reaction time, the resultant precursor was removed from methanol by filtration and afterwards dried at 95 °C. The prepared materials were named as CaOMe_x where x refers to hydrothermal synthesis times (2, 4, 6 and 8 h). 2.3 Catalyst characterization Thermogravimetric-mass spectrometric analysis (TGA-MS) was carried out in a Mettler Toledo DSC/TGA3+ equipped with a Hiden HPR-20 mass spectrometer operating under an air flow at a temperature rate of 10 °C min-1 from 50 to 1000 °C. Infrared spectra of the catalysts were performed on a Prestige-21 Shimadzu FT-IR spectrometer. Field scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM SU8230) was employed to observe morphologies of catalyst. The crystal structure and crystal size of the catalysts were examined by a SmartLab diffractometer using Cu-Kα as X-ray source operating at 50 kV and 50 mA. The phase structure of the catalysts was analyzed from 5° to 40° with a scan rate of 1°/min. The catalyst textural characteristics were obtained by Brunauer Emmer-Teller (BET) using Micromeristics ASAP 2020. The sample basicity was obtained from CO2-Temperature programmed desorption analysis (CO2-TPD) by a Bel-Cat B instrument. Before analysis, each sample was pretreated under He at 200 °C for 1 h before CO2 adsorption. The CO2 desorption was carried out from 50 to 800 °C with 10 °C min-1 under He flow. The surface chemical state was obtained using X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (AXIS ULTRA DLD) with Al Ka radiation. 2.4 Transesterification reaction procedures The performance of the catalysts on transesterification was performed on a three-neck flask at 160 °C, 3:1 POME:TMP molar ratio, pressure of 100 mbar and catalyst dosage of 5 wt%. For each run, TMP was introduced into the flask and placed in a hotplate at 80 °C to melt TMP. After that, POME was added into the flask and the solution was heated to 160 °C. The catalyst was then slowly introduced to the solution followed by applying vacuum pressure of 100 mbar and the mixture was then carried out for a period range of 2 - 6 h. Once the reaction time was completed, the catalyst was separated from the mixture by filtration. To guarantee reproducibility, all experiments were carried out in duplicate. 2.5 Analysis of product The composition of liquid product was identified using a magnetic resonance spectrometer and gas chromatography using a JEOL-ECP 400 spectrometer. The 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectroscopy were performed at 500 MHz and 100.61 MHz, respectively with deuterated chloroform (CDCl3) used as the solvent. POME conversion and biolubricant yield were determined with an Agilent 7890A Gas chromatograph fitted with a DH-5HT column. The POME conversion and biolubricant yield calculations were performed using Eqs. (4) – (5) [12,13]. (4) POME conversion ( % ) = P O M E i n i t i a l − P O M E f i n a l P O M E i n i t i a l x 100 % (5) TE yield ( % ) = T E c o m p o s i t i o n × W e i g h t o f L i q u i d p r o d u c t W e i g h t o f P O M E i n i t i a l x 100 % Inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometric (ICP–AES) analysis (ICPE-9820) was conducted to determine the leaching of Ca active component in biolubricant product. Physical and chemical characteristics of the resulting biolubricant product were assessed following to the ASTM standards: ASTM D2270 (viscosity index), ASTM D97 (pour point), ASTM D2500 (cloud point), and ASTM D92 (flash point). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Representative TGA-MS profile of the CaOMe sample revealed (Fig.S1(a)) two distinct mass loss stages. The first centered around 370 - 460 °C exhibited mass loss of approximately 16 wt.%. The second, occurring at 590 - 825 °C, accounted for a total mass loss of 26 wt.%. The main gases evolved during thermal decomposition of CaOMe catalyst was CO2 (m/z = 44) and water (m/z = 18). The first stage was related to degradation of Ca(OCH3)2 to form CaCO3 (Ca(OCH3)2 + O2 → CaCO3 + CO2 + 3H2O). The second stage indicated the decomposition of CaCO3 to CaO. The TG/DTG results illustrated the CaOMe catalyst was highly stable in the transesterifcation [11]. Fig. 1 (a) displays FT-IR analysis of CaOMe, where the peak at 1067 cm-1 corresponded to the C–O and –OH groups of primary alcohol. The absorption peaks observed at 1465 and 2750–2980 cm-1 represented –C–H alkene bending and CH3 stretching vibrations, respectively. The peak at 3640 cm-1 corresponded with –OH groups of primary alcohol or the adsorbed moisture on the exterior of CaOMe [8]. Representative FESEM images of all samples are displayed in Fig. 2 , where the parent CaO showed an irregular-shaped structure with a large particle size of 1368 nm (Table 1 ). In contrast, smaller particle sizes were observed for the CaOMe catalysts. As seen in Fig. 2(b), FESEM image of the CaOMe catalyst synthesized in 2 h shows irregular and plate-like structures with an average particle size of 707 nm. Increasing duration time to 4 h, small plate-like shaped particles are clearly observed, and the average size as shown in Table 1 is 404 nm. The CaOMe catalyst synthesized in 6 h showed the smallest size of 215 nm. Particle size distribution (Fig. 2(d)) ranged from 100 to 900 nm, while the highest distribution of particle size was 100 – 200 nm. These results indicated that increasing synthesis time not only promoted uniform structure but also helped decrease the catalyst particle sizes. However, the particle sizes increased dramatically when synthesis time increased to 8 h. Consistent results were observed by TeO et al. [11], revealing that the smaller plate-like shaped particles were observed when hydrothermal synthesis time was 8 h, but when hydrothermal synthesis time increased to 10 and 12 h, the CaOMe particle sizes were mostly aggregated and formed into a larger crystal structure. XRD profiles of the CaO and CaOMe_x are shown in Fig. 1(b), where the peak centered at 10.8° suggested the existence of Ca(OCH3)2, while those at 17.8°, 28.6°, and 34.0° were assigned to the Ca(OH)2, which can be formed via the interaction of water with the catalyst surface. Diffraction peaks of CaO were 2θ of 32.1° and 37.2° [14]. Additionally, Table 1 shows the crystal sizes of all samples, determined using the Scherrer's equation. The CaO size was 135.2 nm, while CaOMe was in the range of 43.3 – 51.3 nm. The smallest crystal size of 43.3 nm was achieved by hydrothermal synthesis time of 6 h, which was consistent with FESEM results. Similar findings were also reported in the previous study [14,15]. The size of CaOMe was smaller compared to CaO indicating that the hydrothermal synthesis method was effective in preparing a catalyst with small particle size, and the synthesis time played a crucial role in controlling catalyst morphologies and particle sizes. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of CaO and CaOMe catalysts are presented in Fig 3 (a). Both catalysts showed isotherm type IV with hysteresis loop, indicating the presence of mesopores. The increase in N2 adsorption-desorption at higher relative pressure observed for the CaOMe catalyst may be related to its plate-like structures, which enhance surface accessibility and pore connectivity. Notably, the CaOMe_6 h catalyst exhibited smaller plate-like structures, further improving its textural properties. Table 1 summarized the surface area of all samples, where CaO exhibited 20 m2g-1. The specific surface area of CaOMe_x was 27 - 38 m2g-1, respectively. These findings align with the results obtained in previous studies. Liu et al. [8] prepared nano-Ca(OCH3)2 catalyst with surface area of 19 m2g-1, while Mittal et al. [14] also found that the surface area of nano Ca(OCH3)2 catalyst was 27 m2g-1. The surface area of nano-CaOMe obtained in this study was higher than that reported in previous studies. As illustrated in Table 1, the highest surface area of 38 m2g-1 was obtained from the hydrothermal synthesis of 6 h, which may be due to its smaller particle size. Pore volume and pore size of the CaO catalyst were 0.0492 cm3g-1 and 9.65 nm, respectively, while the CaOMe catalyst exhibited larger pore volume and pore size. The CaOMe_6 h exhibited the highest pore volume and pore size. Among the synthesized catalysts, CaOMe_6 h demonstrated the highest pore volume and pore size, indicating superior textural properties. The BJH pore size distribution of the catalyst as depicted in Fig 3(b), indicates that CaO exhibits both mesopores (2–5 nm) and macropores (6–40 nm). In contrast, the CaOMe catalyst displayed a narrower and more uniform pore size distribution, suggesting improved structural homogeneity. The surface area and pore size play a key role in solid catalysts since they are closely contributed to catalytic performance. Similar observations were reported by Teo et al. [11]. They also found that the large pore size could improve the accessibility of bulky POME and leads reagents to the ultimate reaction sites. Fig. 1(c). shows the CO2-TPD of all samples, and the total amount of basicity of each sample is presented in Table 1. It was previously reported that the desorption peaks between 300 and 550 °C were considered as weak and medium basic sites, while above 550 °C were assigned to strong basic sites [16]. From Fig. 1(c), the CaO sample showed two desorption peaks, the first peak at 300 – 450 °C, and second peak at 500 – 690 °C, whereby the total basic value obtained at weak and strong basic sites was 6.649 mmol g-1. The CaOMe_x catalysts exhibited stronger peak intensities and broader peaks in the higher temperature range with total basic content of 11.146 - 15.894 mmol g-1. The results indicated that the transformation of CaO to CaOMe_x led to strengthen the catalyst basicity. As illustrated in Table 1, increasing hydrothermal synthesis time from 2 h to 6 h led to an increase in basicity, but when increasing time to 8 h the basicity increased dramatically. The TPD results aligned with the results from FESEM, XRD and BET, indicating that synthesis time involved in controlling both physical and chemical characteristics of catalysts. XPS was conducted to analyze the species on the catalyst surface. Fig. 4 (a) shows XPS wide scan spectrum of CaO and CaOMe_x samples. The spectra show the photoelectron peaks associated with C, Ca and O atoms [17]. Fig. 4(b) reveals the XPS spectrum deconvoluted of C 1 s excitation having a main peak in a binding energy of 282 - 290 eV, which was deconvoluted into four peaks, indicating the presence of different carbon species. The peaks obtained at 284.5 eV, 285.8 eV corresponded to CC with sp2 and sp3, respectively, while the peaks at 287.2 eV and 289.4 eV were associated with CO and C = O, respectively [18]. The deconvolution of the Ca 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. 4(c)) displayed two peaks at binding energies of 347.08 and 350.60 eV signifying Ca 2p3/2 and Ca 2p1/2, respectively. As illustrated in Fig. 4(d), the XPS profile deconvoluted of O 1s region of all catalysts showed broad spectra in a binding energy range from 531.5 – 529.8 eV, which can be deconvoluted into three peaks. The first was originated from the O2− species in Ca-O bond, while the other two peaks were assigned to the oxygen species in carbonate and/or water. It has been reported that the O2− species reflected the basicity of calcium oxide [19,20]. The decrease in binding energy of the O2− species led to an increase in the basic strength. As seen in Fig 3(d), O 1s binding energy of the CaOMe catalyst gradually shifted to lower binding energy with increasing synthesis time, implying that the electron donating capability of surface oxygen atoms gradually increased and more basic sites were formed on the catalyst surface [21]. These results agreed well with the CO2-TPD results. The transformation of CaO to CaOMe_x led to improve the basicity of the catalyst, while prolonged hydrothermal synthesis time resulted in a stronger basicity of CaOMe_x. 3.2 Catalytic activity The performances of CaOMe prepared from different synthesis times and CaO catalysts on transesterification of POME and TMP were tested at 160 °C, 100 mbar, 3:1 POME:TMP molar ratio, 5 w/w% catalyst and 6 h reaction time. The GC analysis of the liquid product (Fig. S2) exhibits the disappearance of TMP peak and the decline in POME peak intensity, indicating that the reaction of TMP with POME to produce mono-, di- and tri-ester. The 1H NMR and 13C NMR analyses were also performed to verify the success of transesterification reaction conversion, as shown in Fig. S3. In 1H NMR spectrum, a resonance peak at 4.00 and 4.02 ppm referred to hydrogen of esterified groups (CH2OOC-) in TE and DE, respectively [22]. The 13C NMR spectrum shows resonance peaks at 173.51 and 63.70 ppm corresponding to the characteristic resonance signal of C = O and CO of ester. Hence, both 1H NMR and 13C NMR results showed the formation of ester bond between POME and TMP, indicating that transesterification reaction of POME to polyol ester was successful [23]. According to GC and NMR analyses in this present work and the basis of literature data, the possible reaction mechanism of transesterification of POME and TMP over CaOMe is summarized in Scheme 1 . Transesterification reaction mainly occurred on the catalyst surface, where POME and TMP can be adsorbed on Caδ+ and Oδ- active sites to form intermediate compounds as shown in step (a) and (b). In step (c), both intermediate species reacted with each other to generate ME of TMP and methanol as a by-product. The ME can further react with another TMP molecule to form DE and TE [15,24]. Fig. 5 shows the progress of POME conversion and product yield at different reaction times. According to the results, as the reaction time increased there was an upward trend for both CaO and CaOMe_x catalysts. After 6 h reaction time, the CaO catalyst exhibited 78 % POME conversion, and the CaOMe_x catalysts exhibited 81–89 % POME conversion. The CaO catalyst clearly exhibited low catalytic activity in POME conversion but when treated it with methanol and formed Ca(OCH3)2, the catalytic activity significantly increased because of its high basic properties and small particles (Table 1). Similar observations have been previously reported for catalytic transesterification over heterogenous calcium oxide catalyst [8]. In addition to POME conversion, the CaOMe catalyst showed higher ester yield and more selective to TE product, reaching 62 - 80 % after 6 h reaction time. However, the selectivity to TE product was 45 % when the CaO was used. In the methoxide catalyst system, the TE yield followed the order: CaOMe_6 > CaOMe_4 > CaOMe_8 > CaOMe_2, respectively. The catalyst activity was correlated with physicochemical characteristics of catalysts. The CaOMe_6 catalyst showed more selective to TE product as it showed higher TE yield. With a reaction time of 4 h, a TE yield of 66 % and trace amount of DE product were detected for the CaOMe_6 catalyst, while at the same reaction time, TE and DE yields of 57 % and 13 % were obtained over the CaOMe_4 catalyst. According to BET, XRD, FESEM and CO2-TPD results, the higher activity on the CaOMe_6 catalyst compared to other catalysts was likely due to its higher surface area, smaller particle sizes, higher basicity, as evidenced by BET, FESEM and CO2-TPD analyses. In addition, the effect of vacuum pressure on the transesterification reaction was investigated using 5 w/w% CaOMe_6 catalyst at 160 °C and 3:1 POME:TMP molar ratiofor 6 h. Table 2 summarizes the results of this study. It can be clearly seen that decreasing pressure from 100 mbar to 20 mbar significantly improved both POME conversion and TE yield. This can be explained by the improvement of methanol removal from the reaction mixture. The low pressure facilitated the removal of methanol, shifting the reaction to the right side and resulting in higher TE yield [5]. 3.3 Parametric studies According to the results above, the physicochemical characteristics of the catalysts were crucial in determining TE yield. To understand which characteristics of the catalysts had the most effect on TE yield, a parametric study was performed using experimental data. TE yield obtained from 160 °C, 3: 1 POME:TMP molar ratio, reaction time 6 h and pressure 100 mbar was plotted against the characteristics of the catalysts (CaO, CaOMe_2, CaOMe_4, CaOMe_6 and CaOMe_8) representing both the physical and chemical behaviors each catalyst (Fig. S4). The obtained findings found that the correlation coefficients (R2) between TE yield and surface area, pore volume, pore size, particle sizes and total basic sites were 0.8999, 0.8244, 0.4724, 0.8582 and 0.8884, respectively. These results indicate that surface area, pore volume, particle sizes and total basic sites have significant influence on TE yield, whereas pore size exhibited a weaker correlation. In addition, the correlation coefficient (R²) for TE yield against the combined effect of surface area, pore volume, particle size, and total basic sites was 0.5914 (Fig.S4(f)). Notably, the combination of surface area and total basic sites exhibited the highest correlation, indicating that these two parameters play the most significant role in improving TE yield. In addition, a regression model for correlation of TE yield and the two important parameters (i.e., surface area and total basic site) was also established and the findings are shown in Table 3 . The resulting equation was shown in Eq. (6), where A and B are surface area and total basic site, respectively. (6) Yield ( % ) = 13 . 519 + 0 . 878 A + 2 . 302 B The correlation graph of the actual experimental data against the predicted TE yield (Fig. S5) illustrates the good agreement between the predicted and the experimental TE yield with a relatively small absolute average deviations (AAD < 0.1 %), implying that the regression model given by Eq. (6) fits well with the system. The value for coefficient A and B were statistically significant for TE yield. According to Eq. (6), the value of coefficient B was larger than that of coefficient A, indicating that basic strength played a bigger role in TE yield. 3.3 Reusability testing To examine the catalyst reusability, the spent Ca(OCH3)2_6 was separated from the synthesized biolubricant by simple filtration and reused for the next cycle. As seen on Fig. 6 . POME conversion decreased from 96 % in the first cycle to 85 % after 6 cycles of transesterification reaction and the TE yield decreased to 59 %. The TGA-MS profile of the catalyst after 6 consecutive cycles is shown in Fig.S6. The TGA-MS analysis showed mass losses associated with the evolution of water (m/z = 18), CO2 (m/z = 44), which could be attributed to decomposition of CaOMe, producing water and CO2, as well as the combustion of organic molecules that covered on the surface of the catalyst [25]. Additionally, the TGA-MS indicated the presence of trimethylpropane, an unreacted compound that remained on the catalyst surface. The decline in POME conversion and TE yield may be attributed to the reduced availability of active catalytic sites caused by the deposition of these organic molecules. The decrease in POME conversion was also attributed to catalyst leaching. The Ca content in the biolubricant was determined by ICP-AES, as shown in Table 4 . The results revealed that while the Ca content was negligible in fresh POME, it progressively increased with each reusability cycle, rising from 32.91 ppm in the first cycle to 211.58 ppm in the sixth cycle. This indicates continuous Ca leaching, which contributed to the gradual decline in catalytic activity. Furthermore, the leaching of Ca led to a decrease in the XRD intensity of CaO (Fig. 1), confirming the loss of the active phase over multiple cycles. 3.4 Comparison of the Ca(OCH3)2 nanocatalyst with different heterogeneous catalysts for biolubricant production Table 5 summarizes the helpful information of reaction conditions including catalyst used, feedstock temperature, time, molar ratio of methyl ester and TMP and pressure for comparison with the Ca(OCH3)2 nanocatalyst in the present study. The non-treated calcium methoxide required higher POME:TMP molar ratio, longer reaction time and higher temperature when compared with the Ca(OCH3)2 nanocatalyst obtained in the present study. Besides, compared with other heterogenous catalysts operating under low pressure, the Ca(OCH3)2 nanocatalyst exhibited significant advantages in reducing energy consumption for vacuum process. 3.5 Physicochemical properties of biolubricant Physical and chemical characteristics of the resulting biolubricant product under reaction conditions of 5 wt.% CaOMe_6 catalyst, 3:1 POME:TMP molar ratio, at 160 °C and 20 mbar pressure were assessed following the ASTM standards. The results, summarized in Table 6 show the viscosities of the obtained biolubricant at 40 and 100 °C along with viscosity index and flash point aligned closely to those of ISO VG 46 mineral oil and other reported biolubricants. However, the pour point was relatively higher, which can be attributed to the high saturated fatty acid content in the TE product. The results indicated that the obtained biolubricant might be only suitable for using as lubricant in the tropical climate countries with no winter season. Modifications such as incorporating additives or modifying the raw materials are required to enhance its usability in a broader climatic condition. 4 Conclusions This study demonstrated the production of biolubricant using nano-Ca(OCH3)2 catalyst as an efficient and recyclable catalyst. The nano-calcium methoxide catalyst was prepared using hydrothermal method and effect of hydrothermal synthesis time (1–6 h) on catalytic properties and performances was examined. Characterization of the catalysts indicated that hydrothermal synthesis time had a crucial impact on the physiochemical characteristics of catalyst. The catalyst prepared by 6 h synthesis time exhibited the best characteristics and effective in catalyzing transesterification for biolubricant production with 80 % of yield. Additionally, the recycling experiment results revealed that the catalyst had excellent reutilization and could maintain POME conversion of 85 % after use for 6 cycles. The physical and chemical properties of the resulting biolubricant were similar to those of ISO VG 46 mineral oil, especially in terms of viscosity and flash point. coredata.dc:description: The present work investigated the biolubricant production from palm oil-based methyl ester over calcium methoxide nanocatalyst. The hydrothermal method was employed in this work to prepare nano-calcium methoxide. The difference of hydrothermal synthesis time influenced on the catalytic characteristics and performances was studied. The catalytic activity showed a significant dependence on the catalyst's basic sites and particle size, achieving a palm oil methyl ester conversion of 78–89 % and a selectivity of 62–80 % for biolubricant production. The calcium methoxide with a hydrothermal synthesis time of 6 h exhibited superior catalytic activity to the other catalysts as a result of its small particle size and high basicity. Additionally, the calcium methoxide catalyst apparently showed good stability and reutilization, with palm oil methyl ester conversion of 85 % after use for 6 consecutive cycles. The physicochemical properties of the obtained biolubricant aligned closely the ISO VG 46 mineral oil, especially regarding viscosity and flash point. However, due to its high pour point, the obtained biolubricant may be most suitable for applications in tropical climates without winter conditions
